content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see five discrete pieces of tissue, which based on their ovoid shape and general architecture, are consistent with lymph nodes. They vary in size and staining pattern. Some nodes appear almost entirely replaced by basophilic (purple) tissue, while others have a mix of eosinophilic (pink) and basophilic areas. The top-left node, in particular, shows a distinct, irregular, dark purple area replacing a portion of the normal lymphoid tissue, which is highly suspicious for metastatic disease.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the first lymph node from the top-left. This node is a high-priority target for examination because it clearly displays an abnormal area. There is a sharp demarcation between the expected uniform appearance of a lymph node and a more disorganized, intensely basophilic (dark purple) region. This pattern is a strong indicator of metastatic carcinoma replacing the normal lymphoid parenchyma, and a closer look is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and assess the characteristics of the tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the third lymph node from the left. This node is largely eosinophilic, suggesting it is mostly necrotic. In cases of necrotic lymph nodes, it is crucial to carefully examine the capsule and the immediate surrounding perinodal fat. This area is a high-yield location to find any remaining viable tumor cells, assess for capsular invasion, and, most importantly, identify extranodal extension (ENE), where the tumor has breached the capsule and invaded the surrounding fatty tissue. ENE is a critical prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the third lymph node from the left. This node is almost entirely replaced by a pale, necrotic-appearing tumor. The zoom target is the periphery of the node, at the interface between the necrotic core and the surrounding tissue. This is the most critical area to examine for two reasons: 1) to find viable tumor cells to confirm the metastasis, and 2) to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is defined as the tumor breaching the lymph node capsule and invading the surrounding fat. This has significant prognostic implications. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area, which is located on the third lymph node from the top (or the middle one on the right). This node is almost completely effaced and replaced by a large, homogeneous eosinophilic mass. This appearance is strongly suggestive of a metastatic deposit with extensive central necrosis. I am specifically targeting the interface between the central necrotic area and the peripheral, more cellular rim of tissue. This is the highest-yield area to identify viable tumor cells to confirm the metastasis and assess the host response. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the third lymph node from the left. This node is morphologically distinct from the others due to its large, pale, eosinophilic center. This appearance is highly suspicious for extensive tumor necrosis within a metastatic lymph node. I would zoom into the periphery of this necrotic area, at the interface with the more cellular rim, to search for any remaining viable tumor cells to confirm the metastasis. The capsule area is also important to assess for extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. This is the fifth lymph node from the top (at the bottom left). I zoomed into this specific area because it appears densely cellular and dark blue (basophilic) at low power. This appearance can be due to a prominent reactive lymphoid follicle or a solid deposit of metastatic tumor. High magnification is necessary to differentiate between these two possibilities by evaluating the cellular morphology and architecture. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly identify metastatic adenocarcinoma. There are poorly formed, crowded glandular structures with features typical of colorectal cancer, including cribriform patterns and intraluminal necrotic debris (so-called "dirty necrosis"). The tumor cells show significant nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromasia. The tumor is infiltrating the lymphoid tissue, and on the top right, it appears to be adjacent to or involving the lymph node capsule. My impression is a lymph node positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding tissue. At the top, there is mature adipose tissue (perinodal fat). At the bottom, there is an acellular, eosinophilic, and hemorrhagic area, consistent with the necrotic core of the lymph node. In between is a thickened, fibrotic band representing the lymph node capsule. This capsule contains spindle cells, scattered chronic inflammatory cells, and a small lymphoid aggregate on the left. I do not see definitive malignant glands or single tumor cells in this specific field. My impression is that this area shows a fibrotic capsule adjacent to a necrotic node. The extensive necrosis is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma, and I would need to meticulously scan the entire circumference of this node to find viable tumor and assess for extranodal extension.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image clearly shows the interface between two distinct zones. The lower portion consists of acellular, eosinophilic material with ghost outlines of cells, which is coagulative necrosis. The upper portion shows a dense, cellular infiltrate of malignant cells with large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. These tumor cells are seen infiltrating into the adjacent adipose tissue at the top right, extending beyond a fibrous capsule. My impression is a lymph node massively involved by metastatic adenocarcinoma with extensive necrosis and clear evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see a large area of acellular, granular, eosinophilic material on the left, which is characteristic of extensive tumor necrosis. On the right, there is a rim of residual lymphoid tissue with a dense inflammatory infiltrate. Critically, at the junction between the necrosis and the lymphoid tissue, there are infiltrating nests and poorly formed glands of malignant cells. These cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. My impression is that this is unequivocally metastatic adenocarcinoma within a lymph node. This is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the wall of the lymph node. At the top, there is a large expanse of eosinophilic, acellular material consistent with coagulative necrosis. The wall itself is thickened, fibrotic, and contains a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, including lymphocytes and some neutrophils. There are also areas of hemorrhage (red blood cells). At the very bottom, perinodal adipose tissue is visible. In this specific field, definitive viable malignant cells are not clearly seen. However, the combination of extensive necrosis within a lymph node in a colorectal cancer setting is highly suggestive of a positive (metastatic) node. I would meticulously examine the entire circumference of this node to find a focus of viable carcinoma to confirm the diagnosis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, I see a dense, well-circumscribed proliferation of lymphocytes, consistent with a lymphoid follicle. The cells are small, with round, dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are features of normal lymphocytes. There are no atypical cells, glandular structures, or nests of malignant epithelial cells to suggest metastasis. Some dark pigment, likely carbon (anthracosis) or hemosiderin, is present in macrophages. My impression is that this is a reactive lymphoid follicle within a benign lymph node, with no evidence of malignancy in this field of view.
